* A launcher class to workaround classpath issues.

* This is the main class of the Trackr application. The Trackr application is an interface of a
* to-do list that helps users manage a variety of tasks. This class creates the GUI for Trackr using FXML.
* Controller for MainWindow. Provides the layout for the other controls.
* Creates two dialog boxes, one echoing user input and the other containing Duke's reply and then appends them to
* the dialog container. Clears the user input after processing.
* Deals with loading tasks from the file and saving tasks in the file.
* Deals with interactions with the user.
* This is the class constructor assigning a filepath to the Duke object.
* The Command class is an abstract class for all valid commands. All valid commands inherits from this class.
* This is an abstract method that executes the correct actions based on the command.
* @param ui Deals with interactions with the user
* @param storage Deals with loading tasks from the file and saving tasks in the file
public abstract String execute(TaskList tasks, Ui ui, Storage storage);
* Class when user issues a Deadline command.

* Adds a Deadline task to the task list.

* @param storage Deals with loading tasks from the file and saving tasks in the file
public String execute(TaskList tasks, Ui ui, Storage storage) {

+ "Now you have " + tasks.size() + " tasks in the list.";

* Class when user issues a Done command.

throw new TrackrException(":( OOPS!!! Please specify the completed task's number.");

* Class when user issues a Find command.

throw new TrackrException(":( OOPS!!! Please enter your search term.");

* Class when user issues a Todo command.

* @param ui Deals with interactions with the user
* @param storage Deals with loading tasks from the file and saving tasks in the file

assert t != null : "t should not be null";
result += "Got it. I've added this task:\n" + "       [T]" + "[ ]" + ' ' + t + '\n'
+ "     Now you have " + tasks.size() + " tasks in the list.";
throw new TrackrException(":( OOPS!!! The description of a todo cannot be empty.");

* This method rewrites all data in the file. This is used when we have to edit existing data
* Represents a task to be completed by a certain date. A Deadline object
* corresponds to a task represented by a name, type and date.

* @param date The date the task is due
* This method is used to get the type of the deadline task.

* @return String This returns the string representing the deadline task
* This method is used to get the date of the deadline task.
* @return String This returns the string representing the date of the deadline

* corresponds to a task represented by a name, type and date.
* Class constructor assigning name, type and date to the object.
* @param taskName The name of the event
* @param date The date of the event
* This method is used to get the type of the event task.
* @return String This returns the type of the event task
* This method is used to get the string representing the event task.
* @return String This returns the string representing the event task
* This method is used to get the date of the event task.
* @return String This returns the string representing the date of the event
* Represents a task input by the user.
* Boolean indicating whether task has been completed.
* Class constructor assigning name and isDone attribute to the object.
* @param taskName The name of the deadline task
* This method is used to set the task as completed.
* This method is used to get the status of the task.
* @return boolean This indicates whether the task has been completed
* This method is used to get the string representing the status of the task.
* @return String This represents whether the task has been completed
* This method is used to get the type of the task.
* @return String This returns the type of the task
* This method is used to get the string representing the task.
* @return String This returns the string representing the task
* This method is used to get the date of the task.
* @return String This returns the string representing the date of the task
* This method is used to get the name of the task.
* @return String This returns the name of the task in the form of a string
* Represents a task to be completed. A Todo object corresponds to a task
* represented by a name, type and date.
* Class constructor assigning name and type to the object.
* This method is used to get the type of the todo task.
* @return String This returns the type of the todo task
* This method is used to get the string representing the todo task.
* @return String This returns the string representing the todo task
* Represents the list of tasks to be completed. A TaskList contains an arraylist of
* tasks and supports retrieval, addition and deletion operations.
* Contains all tasks to be completed.
* Default constructor when user has no tasks stored from previous session.
* Class constructor that is called when user has tasks stored from previous session.
* @param storage Arraylist of tasks retrieved from storage on hard disk.
* Returns the number of tasks on the list.
* @return int This returns the number of tasks on the list.
* This method retrieves a task using index of the task in the list.
* @return Task This returns the task corresponding to index provided
* This method adds a task to the bottom of the list.
* This method removes a task in the list according to the index provided.
* Deals with interactions with the user.
* Prints greeting message to user on application launch.

Imagine yourself as a director of a play. First you provision the props that you will feature in your play. These can be hand props for your actors to interact with or even set dressings just to liven up the background. You then decide where to layout the props for every scene. With a proper script in hand, you can finally approach a theatre and request for a stage. There on, its just a matter of pulling the curtains on your masterpiece.

A JavaFX application is like a play you are directing. Instead of creating props, you create `Nodes` (`Nodes` are the fundamental building blocks of a JavaFX application), and place them onto a `Scene` (a scene is a graph of `Node`s). Then, you set your `Scene` on a `Stage` provided by JavaFX. When you call `Stage#show()` method, JavaFX renders a window with your `Stage` on it.
### If you are not using Gradle
1. Import the `libs` folder from the SDK into your project (note: `JAVAFX_HOME` is the directory in which you have unzipped the JavaFX SDK).
1. From `Run` > `Edit Configurations`, add the following line into your `VM options` for each of the `main` classes.
Update your `build.gradle` to include the following lines:

As customary, lets start off with a simple Hello World program. Modify your `Duke` class to extend `javafx.application.Application`. This requires you to override the `Application#start()` method and provide a concrete implementation. Notice that the method signature for `Application#start()` has a parameter `Stage`. This is the _primary stage_ that JavaFX provides.
Label helloWorld = new Label("Hello World!"); // Creating a new Label control
Scene scene = new Scene(helloWorld); // Setting the scene to be our Label
stage.setScene(scene); // Setting the stage to show our screen
Note how we have created a `Label` to contain the text that we want to show. We then create the `Scene` and set its content. Finally, we set the stage and show it.
Next, we create another Java class, `Launcher`, as an entry point to our application.
The `Launcher` class is reproduced below in its entirety.
* A launcher class to workaround classpath issues.
Run `Launcher` and you should see something like this:
Congratulations! You have created your first GUI application!
1. We mentioned that `Node`s are the fundamental building blocks of JavaFX and used a `Label` as our root node in the HelloWorld application.
1. What are some of the other types of `Node`s?
1. `Node`s can be interacted with like Plain Old Java Objects (POJO).
1. What properties of a `Label` can you change programmatically?
1. Try changing the `Label` to have a font of Arial at size 50.
1. Youve learnt that a `Stage` can be thought of as a window.
1. Can you have more than one `Stage` an application?
1. Try creating another stage and showing it! What happens?
# JavaFX Tutorial 3  Interacting with the user
Picking up from where we left off last tutorial, we have successfully achieved the desired layout. Now lets make the application respond to user input.
Rather than to do everything in one try, lets iterate and build up towards our final goal.

JavaFX has an _event-driven architecture style_. As such, we programmatically define _handler_ methods to execute as a response to certain _events_. When an event is detected, JavaFX will call the respective handlers.

For Duke, there are two events that we want to respond to, namely the user pressing `Enter` in the `TextField` and left-clicking the `Button`. These are the `onAction` event for the `TextField` and the `onMouseClicked` event for the `Button`.
For now, lets have the application add a new `Label` with the text from the `TextField`. Update the `Main` class as follows. You'll need to add an `import javafx.scene.control.Label;` too.
//Step 3. Add functionality to handle user input.
* Creates a label with the specified text and adds it to the dialog container.
* @param text String containing text to add
* @return a label with the specified text that has word wrap enabled.
Run the program and give it a whirl!

At first glance everything appears to work perfectly. However, when the `VBox` stretches beyond the confines of the `ScrollPane`, the `ScrollPane` does not scroll down automatically as expected. We can remedy this by attaching a handler on the `VBox` to react to its own size changing and scrolling the `ScrollPane` down.
Update the `start` method as shown below.
//Scroll down to the end every time dialogContainer's height changes.
Verify that the `ScrollPane` scrolls as intended.

In the mockup of the UI, notice that the dialog boxes are composed of two different controls (`ImageView` and `Label`) and reused multiple times. In situations like this, it is often beneficial to create our own custom control.
We use the code in our main class just like any other control. Here are the steps to update the code to use the custom control in `Main.java`.
Next, add two images to the `main/resources/images` folder.
For this tutorial, we have two images `DaUser.png` and `DaDuke.png` to represent the user avatar and Duke's avatar respectively but you can use any image you want.
Add a new method to handle user input:
* Creates two dialog boxes, one echoing user input and the other containing Duke's reply and then appends them to
* the dialog container. Clears the user input after processing.
* You should have your own function to generate a response to user input.

Run the program and see how it works.
## Iteration 3  Adding custom behavior to DialogBox

One additional benefit of defining a custom control is that we can add behavior specific to our `DialogBox`. Lets add a method to flip a dialog box such that the image on the left to differentiate between user input and Dukes output.
* Flips the dialog box such that the ImageView is on the left and text on the right.

* Add background color to each dialog box
